raw_extractions.description: Led the effort to abolish the death penalty in France, influenced legal changes including decriminalizing homosexuality, and improved prison conditions.
supporting_quotes: Robert Badinter, Former French Justice Minister, and Death Penalty Abolitionist, Dies at 95
In 1981, one of his first official actions as Justice Minister was to seek the abolition of the death penalty in France.
Mr. Badinter served as France’s Minister of Justice from 1981 to 1986, where he overcame public support for the death penalty and gained parliamentary support for abolition.

      ]

      ]
    },
    {
      "organization": "France’s Constitutional Council",
      "role": "President",
      "location": "France",
      "start_date": "1986",
      "end_date": null,
      "description": "Reviewed French law to ensure it aligns with the constitution.",

      ]

    {
      "organization": "French Senate",
      "role": "Representative of the Socialist Party",
      "location": "France",
      "start_date": "1995",
      "end_date": "2011",
      "description": "Served as a progressive defender of the rule of law.",
      "supporting_quotes": [
        "Following his role as president, Mr. Badinter served in the French Senate as a representative of the Socialist party from 1995 to 2011, where 'he progressively came to resemble the conscience of the republic, a fervent defender of the rule of law.'"

    }
  ]
}

OSCE Court’s President and Vice-President meet with OSCE Parliamentary Assembly Leaders

raw_extractions.description: Abolished the death penalty in France under President François Mitterrand.
supporting_quotes: Badinter, a socialist and humanist, will be remembered for his part in abolishing capital punishment, one of his first acts as French justice minister under the socialist president François Mitterrand, a post he held until 1986.

raw_extractions.description: Began his career under the tutelage of Henry Torrès, defending various clients including celebrities and notorious criminals.
supporting_quotes: Badinter began his career in Paris in the early 1950s, under the tutelage of a charismatic lawyer, Henry Torrès, who told him: ‘You defend a man who has killed or stolen because they are first of all a man.’

raw_extractions.description: Represented high-profile clients and defended individuals sentenced to death, including a convicted child murderer.
supporting_quotes: he represented not only celebrities such as Coco Chanel, Charlie Chaplin, Brigitte Bardot and Raquel Welch, but also Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the former Pakistan prime minister, as well as notorious criminals and a convicted child murderer who was among five people he defended who were sentenced to death.

raw_extractions.description: Published a book titled 'The Execution' in 1973, detailing his experiences with the death penalty.
supporting_quotes: In his book The Execution, published in 1973, Badinter recalled watching the killing of a man he had represented, and described the ‘sharp snap’ of the guillotine blade.

raw_extractions.description: Presented and pushed through the law removing the death penalty, earning the nickname 'Monsieur Abolition'. Also decriminalized homosexual relations and ended special military courts.
supporting_quotes: In 1981, as the new justice minister, he presented the law removing the death penalty and pushed it through parliament, earning the nickname “Monsieur Abolition”.

He also enacted Mitterrand’s election promise to decriminalise homosexual relations between those aged over 15 years, the same as for heterosexuals, and ended the “special” military courts that operated outside the regular legal system.

raw_extractions.description: Studied law and literature after the liberation.
supporting_quotes: After the liberation, Badinter studied law and literature at university in Paris and at Columbia University in New York.
